abstract.preview: [PAGE 1] Abstract: Blockchain is a peer-to-peer trustless network that keeps records of digital assets without [PAGE 1] any central authority. With the passage of time, the sustainability issue of blockchain is rising. This [PAGE 1] paper discusses two major sustainability issues of blockchain: power consumption and scalability. [PAGE 1] It discusses the challenge of power consumption by analyzing various approaches to estimating [PAGE 1] power consumption in the literature. A case study of bitcoin is presented for this purpose. The study [PAGE 1] presents a review of the growing energy consumption of bitcoin along with a solution for immersion [PAGE 1] cooling in blockchain mining. The second challenge addressed in this research is scalability. With [PAGE 1] the increase in network size, scalability issues are also increasing as the number of transactions per [PAGE 1] second is decreasing. In other words, blockchain is observing low throughput with its increase in [PAGE 1] size.

introduction.preview: [PAGE 1] 1. Introduction [PAGE 1] In the current world, centralized systems govern the majority of ﬁnancial transactions [PAGE 1] between people or businesses. In other cases, they can be managed by a third-party [PAGE 1] organization. In the case of a digital payment or transfer between two businesses, a bank or [PAGE 1] credit card vendor, for example, functions as a third party. All successful transactions are [PAGE 1] paid for by the client ﬁrms. A third-party ﬁrm handles and manages practically all of the [PAGE 1] interaction in the online process in this one-size-ﬁts-all approach. This approach obviously [PAGE 1] requires the use of a third party to ensure the transaction’s security. A blockchain, on the [PAGE 1] other hand, is a widely dispersed and securely managed peer-to-peer network where no [PAGE 1] third party is necessary to handle information and trust between network users. [PAGE 1] Blockchain technology is a cutting-edge concept with a promising future.
